abstract.p: The purpose of this article is the optimization of piezoelectric patch positioning for reducing the radiated sound power of thin plates. To this end, an aluminium plate equipped with a set of piezoelectric patches connected to a passive circuit is considered.

The difficulties in designing a smart structure are not only related to the conception of the electric circuit used as controller, but also to the choice of how the circuit itself is coupled with the structure. The selection of the number of transducers to be used, and their positioning, is a crucial step in the designing process. In this work the entire design process of a smart structure is proposed, with the goal of obtaining the best efficiency in terms of reduction of radiated sound power, while using a lightweight optimization procedure in terms of computational costs. To this end, classical instruments of vibrations mechanics are used together with acoustic concepts, such as the modal radiation efficiency. The introduction of this acoustic characterization of the structure in the optimization process is done by using a new utility function, the acoustic controllability, which will be used for the optimization of transducer positioning. The proposed optimization process is applied to the case study of an aluminium plate with nonstandard boundary conditions, and experimental results confirm the validity of this novel procedure.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: The control of the sound generated from a plane structure is a challenging topic in engineering, especially in the design of more comfortable and reliable vehicles. Piezoelectric-based control systems are widely used in the literature as a means to introducing structural damping, or, more generally, for reducing radiated sound power. In this paper we will focus our attention on passive controllers optimized for the reduction of the acoustic radiation of a thin metallic plate. The choice of a passive controller is motivated by the fact that, since a passive circuit cannot supply power to the mechanical system, consequently it cannot cause instability. Moreover, for each piezoelectric element is a co-located sensor–actuator pair, the positioning of which does not influence the stability of the system.

When conceiving a smart structure optimized for reducing the radiated sound power, the choice of transducer positioning is a crucial step, mainly because it greatly influences the energy exchange between the mechanic and electric parts of the circuit, and then affects the overall behaviour and efficacy of the controller. This optimization depends on several factors, such as the dimensions of the structure and the choice of the materials, but also on the physical quantity that one wants to control. This means that a system optimized for controlling vibrations, in principle, will not assure the best sound radiation control and vice versa. In this specific case, this difference occurs because not all structural vibrations can generate sound. A modal decomposition of the structure easily shows that some vibrational modes are way more efficient than others in terms of radiated sound power, as shown in Ozer and Royston (2003); Fahy (2001) and Kinsler et al. (2000).

In the literature there exists several criteria for performing this optimization, depending on the nature of the structure and of the controller, and a number of articles focus on thin plates. These methods of optimization can be divided in two main categories: closed- and open-loop methods.

Closed-loop methods consider the coupled dynamics of the circuit structure system. These methods often give a finer optimization, since the energy transfer between the mechanic and the electric systems is maximized, but they are often very expensive in terms of computational costs, since a numerical procedure must be used during the optimization.

In Giorgio et al. (2009) the authors employed a closed-loop method using as utility function the minimization of the norm of the frequency response. This optimization uses a finite element method for calculating the frequency response of the whole smart system in function of the positioning, and this lead to a finer result, but also in a considerable increase of the computational costs. In Thomas et al. (2009) a complete finite element analysis of the coupled structure is presented.

Open-loop methods consider the structure without any circuit connected to it. These methods are based on parameters that can be directly derived from the model, such as electromechanic coupling coefficients, strain energy or modal controllability. From the literature it can be found that there are several different works on the optimization procedures for determining the optimal positioning of the transducers for passive vibration control, but it should be noted that these procedures are all based on vibration control optimization, and not on sound radiation control.

The control procedure developed in this work is based on an open-loop optimization, since it does not take into account the controller parameters while choosing the optimal placement. The optimization of the passive circuit is performed after the optimal position is determined, since the efficiency of a tuned passive resonant circuit is only influenced by the electromechanical coupling coefficient (Porfiri et al., 2007). Indeed, closed-loop techniques are more common when considering active controllers, as in this case a considerable increase of the performance is obtained when involving the controller parameters in the optimization (Zhu et al., 2003).

In Sadri et al. (1999) and Flynn and Todd (2010) a genetic algorithm for optimizing the positioning and the number of piezoelectric elements to be used is presented. In Mehrabian and Yousefi-Koma (2007, 2009) bio-based procedures are proposed. However the modal approach seems to be more efficient in terms of computational costs. In Halim and Moheimani (2003) another open-loop technique is presented, and the concept of spatial ℋ norm is introduced. This quantity is used to describe the spatial structural response of the system in an average sense.

Controlling vibrations with a modal approach usually means that every mode has the same importance, and thus the control effort is equally distributed among the entire set of modes, while only a subset of them are effectively able to radiate sound power. Several examples of multi-modal passive control are present in the literature. In Alessandroni et al. (2002); Andreaus et al. (2004); dell'Isola et al. (1998, 2004); Maurini (2004a); Porfiri et al. (2004); Rosi et al. (2010) and Vidoli and dell'Isola (2001) the authors use a distributed network of transducers, removing the need to optimize their positioning. This concept can also be applied to either plates or beams (Alessandroni et al., 2005; Porfiri et al., 2005). When controlling the low-order modes, a switch-shunting controller can also be used (Ducarne et al., 2010). However, approaching the vibrational problem from an acoustical point of view (Ohayon and Soize, 1998; Fahy, 1985; Cremer, 1973), it is clear that there are some modes that radiate more efficiently than the others, and this is due to several factors such as the modal shapes, the geometry of the system and of its boundaries and the natural frequencies. An acoustic-based optimization of the circuit parameter, but not of the positioning, is presented in Ozer and Royston (2003), which also considers the hysteresis of the piezoelectric materials. This means that a smaller number of elements can be used. Following these considerations, the objective of this work is the extension of the concept of spatial ℋ introduced in Halim and Moheimani (2003) to the acoustic optimization of the smart structure. This will be performed with the introduction of a novel utility function, here called the acoustic controllability, which describes the acoustic response of the system in an average sense and permits us to concentrate the control effort over the modes with a higher radiation efficiency. The originality of this procedure is rooted in the fact that it involves deeply the acoustic properties of the structure in the choice of the piezoelectric positioning and of the number of transducers to be used.

The first section of the paper is devoted to the introduction of the equations describing the considered electromechanical system. Section 3 is a general introduction to the acoustic properties of thin structures, and introduces all the performance indices that will be used in the optimization. A detailed analysis of the radiation properties of thin plates is included, along with the definition of the modal radiation efficiency. In section 4 the acoustically based optimization procedure for the piezoelectric actuator positioning is presented, using the novel concept of acoustical controllability. Finally, section 5 resumes the experimental work regarding the optimization of a localized piezoelectric smart structure, following the procedures described in section 4. The full process of conception and assembly of the smart structure is described here in detail. Acoustic measurements of the radiated sound pressure are presented, in order to confirm the effectiveness of the proposed control strategy.

sec.title: 2. Equations of the smart plate
sec.p: In this section the equations of the smart plate equipped with a network of piezoelectric transducers are introduced. For the sake of simplicity the modeling procedure has been summarized, and the modal model of the structure is given. Examples of how to go through this modeling process can be easily found in the literature (Alessandroni et al., 2002, 2005; Guyader, 2006; Maurini, 2004b, 2006; Rosi et al., 2010). The details of the procedure can be found in Rosi et al. (2010).

sec.title: 2.1. Reduced modal model
sec.p: Let us consider a plate with a set of M piezoelectric transducers bonded to each face with opposite polarization, known in the literature as bimorph configuration.

The nondimensional reduced modal model of a smart plate in the time domain when considering N modes can be represented in the following compact notation: (1a)y··+Ω2y-ΩΓV=f (1b)V ·+(ΩΓ)Ty·=i where y is the vector of the N nondimensional modal coordinates yi, V the vector of the M nondimensional voltages Vi, f the vector of the N nondimensional mechanical forcing terms, i the vector of the M nondimensional currents ir, Ω the N × N diagonal matrix of the nondimensional circular eigenfrequencies Ωii and Γ the M × N matrix of electromechanical couplings γir. The dot superscript denotes the time derivative.

The nondimensional state variables and forcing terms in system (1) are given, from the respective dimensional quantities Y, V¯, f¯, i and ω by y=Yl0, V=V¯V0, f=f¯F0, i=Ii0, Ω=ωΩ0. with the following scaling voltage, force and current: V0=l0Ω0ρplCp F0=l0Ω02ρpl i0=CrΩ0V0. where Cr is the capacitance of the rth transducer, ρpl the surface mass density of the plate and l0 is a scaling length.

The nondimensional coupling coefficient is given by (2)γir=∫Sχrer∇2(φi)ωiCrρpl, where φi is the modal shape of the ith mode, ∇2 is the laplacian differential operator, χr(x, y) is a piecewise function of the plane defined as 1 in presence of the rth transducer and equal to 0 otherwise, and er is the piezoelectric coupling as defined in the IEEE Standard on Piezoelectricity (IEEE, 1987) where Ω0 is a scaling circular frequency.

In order to introduce symmetry between the mechanical and electrical equations the voltage of the rth transducer Vr can be replaced by the flux linkage Ψr. (3)Ψr=∫Vrdt, Ψ·r=Vr. Then Equations (1a) and (1b) become: (4a)y··+Ω2y-ΩΓΨ·=f (4b)Ψ ··+(ΩΓ)Ty·=i and in the frequency domain: (5a)Ω2y∧-Ω2y∧-jΩ(Ω)ΓΨ∧=f∧ (5b)Ω2Ψ∧+jΩ(ΩΓ)Ty∧=i∧ where the hat superscript denotes a quantity in frequency domain and where Ψ is the vector of the nondimensional flux linkages, given by: (6)Ψ=Ψ¯Ψ0 where the scaling flux linkage is Ψ0=l0ρplCr.

sec.title: 2.2. Multiple shunt circuit
sec.p:
When considering multimodal controller optimization, several techniques are present in the literature. For the sake of simplicity and for showing that the proposed optimization procedure is efficient, a multiple shunt circuit is considered. This is the simplest kind of passive resistor–inductor (RL) resonant shunt for vibration control, and it was introduced for the first time in Hagood and Flotow (1991). It consists of an inductor in parallel with a resistor, shunted to the piezoelectric transducer, as in Figure 1. Figure 1.
Passive resistor–inductor shunt circuit in parallel configuration.

Since a piezoelectric patch can be also represented by a current generator in parallel with a capacitor, Figure 1, the resulting electrical network is a resonant resistor–inductor–capacitor (RLC) circuit. A generalized version of this control circuit is easily obtained using multiple shunted piezoelectric actuators, one for each target mode. The forcing vector introduced in Equations (5a) and (5b) by shunting each transducer with a RL circuit is the following: (7)i=-RRLΨ·-LRLΨ and in the frequency domain: (8)i∧=-jΩRRLΨ∧-LRLΨ∧ where RRL and LRL are two diagonal matrices whose nonzero elements are RiiRL=(1/Ri) and LiiRL=1/(Li).

For each mode it is then possible to write the closed-loop equations as: (9a)Ωi2y∧i+Ω2y∧i+∑r=1MjγirΩΩi∧ψr=fi, (9b)Ω2̂ψr-jΩ1Ω0CrRr̂ψr-1Ω0CrLr̂ψr+∑i=1MjγirΩΩiŷi=0. This system has 2M degrees of freedom (dof), which are the mechanical resonance frequencies Ωi and the electrical resonance frequencies Ω~r=1/(Ω0LrCr). Supposing each transducer is associated to a vibrational mode, the electric tuning and damping coefficient βr and δr can be introduced as: (10)βr=(Ω~iΩi)2=1Ω02Ωi2LrCr, (11)δr=1RrCrΩiΩ0

If the modes are sufficiently spaced in frequency, Equations (9a) and (9b) become: (12a)Ωi2y∧i-Ω2y∧i-jγirΩΩi∧ψr=fi, (12b)Ω2∧ψr+jΩΩiδr∧ψr+Ωi2βr∧ψr+jγirΩΩiy∧i=0. Now that the equations for the closed-loop system have been written, the optimization of the circuit can be performed.

Since both the transient response and the forced response have to be optimized, we will introduce two different quantities: the decay rate D(δ,γ) for the transient response and the mobility function H(Ω,δ,γ) for the forced response, defined as: (13)D(δ)=mini=1,2,3(|Re(λi)|), H(Ω,δ,γ)=jΩy∧i(Ω,δ,γ)f∧i. Where λ1,2,3 are the roots of the characteristic polynomial, and then the poles of the closed-loop system. The parameter that will be optimized is the damping δ and the resulting value δopt will be used in Equation (11) to determine the optimal value for the shunting resistors. This optimization is well known in the literature and the result, for both transient and forced response, is the following: (14)δoptir=3 2γir

sec.title: 3. Sound radiation of plane structures
sec.p: In this section the radiation properties of a finite plate in an infinite baffle are investigated. The main performance indices used for determining the radiation properties of a structure will be introduced, as well as optimized computational methods for calculating these quantities. Finally a modal approach to the estimation of the radiated sound power will be described. The introduction of modal radiation efficiency coefficients will be crucial for the acoustic optimization of the controller proposed in next section.

sec.title: 3.1. Far-field sound pressure
sec.p: The acoustic pressure at a generic point of the space r1 due to the transverse motion w of a portion S of the plate can be calculated using the Rayleigh formula: (15)p∧(r1,ω,S)=jωρf2π∫Se-jk(r1-r)r1-rw∧(r,ω)dS, where the hat superscript denotes a quantity in the frequency domain, |k| = ω/c is the modulus of the wave vector k of a sound wave propagating in a light fluid and r ∈ S, where c is the sound velocity in the medium and ρf the density of the fluid.

This is a very important performance index, since it is related to a physical quantity that can be easily measured, such as the pressure. In the literature there exists a standard method for measuring this quantity, see the ISO Standard 3745:1977.

sec.title: 3.2. Sound power at the plate level
sec.p: The radiated power at the plate level can be expressed by the surface integral of the product between the pressure at each point of the plate, calculated with Equation (15), multiplied by its transverse velocity jωŵ0: (16)πr(ω,S)=1 2∫SRe{(p∧(r,ω)|z=0)·(jωw∧0(r,ω))*}dS, where the asterisk superscript denotes a conjugate quantity.

This global parameter gives different informations with respect to the far-field pressure, since it also involves the near field, but it is not measurable. Unfortunately this double integral very often does not admit an analytical solution, therefore an optimized numerical approach is needed for calculating the radiated sound power.

sec.title: 3.3. Spatial radiation filters and modal radiation efficiency
sec.p: The procedure here proposed has a double advantage, since it reduces the computational cost of calculating the radiated sound power and it permits the introduction of the concept of modal radiation coefficient.

The first step consists of performing a standard modal decomposition of the transverse velocity field of the plate, in terms of the sum of the modal shapes Φi(r) and the corresponding modal velocity coefficients ûi(ω): (17)v∧(ω,r)=∑i=1Nu∧i(ω)Φi(r) Then using Equation (15), the pressure at the point r1 due to the velocity of the point r2, where r1 and r2 are both points of the plate, i.e. (r1, r2) ∈ S, is: (18)p∧(ω,r1)=ρf2π∫Se-jk·(r2-r1)(r2-r1)v∧(ω,r2)dS. Substituting the modal decomposition for the transverse velocity, Equation (17), into Equation (18) gives (19)p∧(ω,r1)=∑i=1Nu∧i(ω)ρf2π∫Se-jωck·(r2-r1)(r2-r1)Φi(r2)dS, that is the modal decomposition for the pressure field. Then substituting Equations (17) and (19) into Equation (16) a reduced modal expression of the radiated power can be written as: (20)π~r=π~self+π~mutual where (21)π~self=∑i=1N|u∧i(ω)|2ρf2π∫S∫SRe{e-jωck·(r2-r1)(r2-r1)Φi(r2)Φi*(r1)}dSdS and (22)π~mutual=∑i=1N∑j=1Nu∧i(ω)u∧j*(ω)ρf2π ×∫S∫SRe{e-jωck·(r2-r1)(r2-r1)Φi(r2)Φj*(r1)}dSdS. This decomposition of the radiated sound power is due to the fact that vibrational modes do not radiate orthogonally. There are mutual radiation terms that contributes to the overall radiated sound power.

In order to simplify the treatment, the self-radiation term can be rewritten as: (23)π~self=∑i=1nηi(ω)|u∧i|2 where (24)ηi(ω)=ρf2π∫S∫SRe{e-jωck·(r2-r1)(r2-r1)Φi(r2)Φi*(r1)}dSdS. Equation (24) defines the modal (self) radiation efficiency for the ith vibration mode of the plate, which depends only on the geometry of the plate and the properties of the fluid. From Equation (23) the self-radiated power is then a quadratic function of the modal velocity, weighted by the modal efficiency coefficient.

The introduction of this coefficient is very important for the optimization of modal controllers, since it permit the easy choice of the most radiating modes among the N modal decompositions. The choice of the self-modal efficiency instead of a more complex term including the mutual radiation terms is motivated by the fact that the most self-radiating modes have a high mutual radiation efficiency too (Elliott and Johnson (1993)). Then controlling the set of modes that have the highest self-radiation efficiency corresponds to a reduction of their radiation efficiency when considering the interaction with the other modes.

Finding the analytical solutions for Equation (24) is still complicated, as was finding the solution of Equation (16), mainly because of the already cited mutual radiation phenomena. Following the literature, see Bai and Tsao (2002); Borgiotti and Jones (1994) and Elliott and Johnson (1993), the plate domain is divided into a matrix of M elements, radiating as pistons. The discrete form of Equation (16) is then: (25)πr(ω)=A2Re{vH(ω)·p(ω)}, where v is the vector of the complex velocities, p is the vector of the pressure immediately in front of each element averaged on the surface A of each element.

The velocity field being known by modal analysis, and given that the pistons are radiating as plane surfaces with transverse velocity, the pressure on the nth piston due to the velocity of the mth can be calculated with the aid of Equation (15) (26)pn(ω)=ρf2π∫Ae-jkrn,mrn,mvm(ω)dS, For a plate in an infinite baffle the pressure vector can be then rewritten as: p=Zv. The discrete form of the radiated sound power is then: πr=vHRe{Z}v=vHRv, where vH denotes the Hermitian of the velocity vector.

The matrix R is a real, symmetric, positive definite matrix whose elements can be analytically calculated: (27)R(ω)=ω2ρfA24πc[1sin(kr1,2)kr1,2…sin(kr1,M)kr1,Msin(kr2,1)kr2,11………………sin(krM,1)krM,1……1], where ρf and c are the density and speed of sound in the air respectively, A the area of the elementary radiating element and rn,m the distance between the nth and the mth piston. For a plate in an infinite baffle the matrix R depends only on the dimensions of the plate and the characteristics of the fluid.

Since R is a real, symmetric, positive definite matrix, an eigenvalue/eigenvector decomposition can always be performed. In compact form it is: R(ω)=QT(ω)Λ(ω)Q(ω), where Q is a N × M matrix, whose columns qi are the eigenvectors, called radiation filters or radiation modes in the literature, and Λ the diagonal matrix of the eigenvalues. These radiation filters qi can be interpreted as optimal velocity patterns in terms of radiation efficiency and they depend on frequency, as well as their associated eigenvalue.

Since R is a large matrix that depends on frequency, performing an eigenvalue/eigenvector decomposition can be a cumbersome task. In Elliott and Johnson (1993) it is shown that the number of radiation modes needed to estimate the radiated sound power increases with the frequency, meaning that this method can be efficiently used only at low frequencies. In the present study we will consider L radiation modes. In this reduced model the reduced eigenvectors and eigenvalues matrix are Q~L×M and Λ~L×L, and consequently the radiation matrix is R~(ω)=Q~T(ω)Λ~(ω)Q~(ω). Each eigenvalue λ~i(ω)=Λ~ii(ω) represents the radiation efficiency of each radiation filter, and its value depends on frequency. For the radiation properties of a plate coupled with a light fluid, these eigenvalues will show high-pass behaviour and for frequencies f > fc, where fc is the critical frequency, they all contribute equally to the radiation. The critical frequency depends only on the geometry of the plate and the properties of the fluid.

Hence, in order to reduce computational costs for calculating the radiated sound power the so-called nesting property of radiation filters, as discussed in Borgiotti and Jones (1994), can be used. Considering two frequencies f1 and f2 so that f1 < f2, the nesting property implies that: (28)Span{q(f1)}⊂Span{q(f2)}. The meaning of the equation (28) is the following: if the eigenvalue corresponding to a radiation filter calculated at f2 is set to zero, that means no radiation, every radiation filter for f1 < f2 will be set to zero as well. Since we are interested in controlling the radiation in a limited frequency band, we use this result to simplify the calculations. After these considerations it is possible to write the final approximated form for the radiation resistances matrix calculated at fmax R~max(ω)=Q~maxTΛ~(ω)Q~max, where Q~max is the matrix of the eigenvectors calculated at fmax, i.e. the maximum frequency of interest. We can now write an approximated equation for the radiated power: π~r(ω)=vH(ω)Q~maxTΛ~(ω)Q~maxv(ω)=∑i=1Rλi|bi|2. where the vector of the coefficients bi is defined by: b(ω)=Q~maxv. Using the compact form of the modal decomposition: v(ω)=Φ(r)u∧(ω), where ΦN×M is the matrix of modal shapes and u∧ is the vector of the Fourier coefficients.

The radiated sound power takes the form: (29)π~r(ω)=(Φu∧(ω))HQ~maxTΛ~(ω)Q~max(Φu∧(ω)) Considering only the self-radiated power one can write: π~self(ω)=u∧H(ω)(Q~maxΦ)HΛ~(ω)(Q~maxΦ)u∧(ω)=u∧H(ω)E~(ω)u∧(ω) where E~(ω)=(Q~maxΦ)HΛ~(ω)(Q~maxΦ) is the diagonal matrix of the approximated modal radiation efficiencies. The expression of the approximated modal efficiency for each structural mode is: (30)η~i(ω)=E~ii(ω)=∑nLλn(ω)q~nmax·Φi. In other words each modal radiation efficiency coefficient is determined by the sum of the projection of that structural mode on each radiation filter, weighted by the efficiency of that filter. Each coefficient η~i is the approximation of the integral radiation coefficient ηi defined in (24). The self-radiated sound power is then: (31)π~self(ω)=∑i=1Nη~i|u∧i|2. These coefficients will be used in the optimization procedure of the controller.

sec.title: 4. Transducer positioning optimization for the control of radiated sound power
sec.p: In this section the optimization procedure for choosing the optimal position for the piezoelectric transducers will be outlined. The results obtained in the previous section will be used.

sec.title: 4.1. About the electromechanical coupling
sec.p: Consider a piezoelectric patch of dimensions Lpx Lpy bonded on a plate. Assuming that one corner of the patch is located at (x, y), the value of the nondimensional coupling coefficient γir(x, y) a function of the position of the transducer is, from Equation (2): (32)γir(x,y)=1SplρplCr∫xx+Lpx∫yy+Lpyerφi(x,y)dxdy From Equation (32) it is clear that the coupling between the rth transducer and the ith mode depends on: i) the positioning (x, y), ii) the dimensions Lpx, Lpy, iii) the material and the thickness of the transducer and of the plate (er, Spl), iv) the modal shapes φi.

In this study, we assume the last three parameters to be set, meaning that the optimization will be performed on a given structure with its boundary conditions and given piezoelectric transducers. Then the quantity to be optimized is the position (x, y), and the utility function for the optimization will be some function of this position.

sec.title: 4.1.1. The requirements of the utility function
sec.p: Since the objective of this optimization is the maximization of the controller authority over the radiated sound power, the efficacy of the controller is maximized using the minimum number of transducers. To this end, the concepts introduced in section 3, and in particular the modal radiation efficiency, are used to choose the utility function.

Since we are considering light piezoelectric patches, we assume that the presence of a transducer does not change the modal shapes. For this reason, the utility function will be calculated for one element, and the local maxima for this function will give the optimal placement of the set of piezoelectric patches.

sec.title: 4.1.2. The sensitivity of human hearing
sec.p: While the physical characteristics of a sound field can be measured with precision by standard acoustic instruments (microphones, filters, spectrum analysers, etc.), the interpretative characteristics of hearing are expressible in terms of subjective parameters that lead to statistical predictions of the judgement of an average listener under assumed or known conditions (Kuttruff, 2007; Kinsler et al., 2000; Everest and Pohlmann, 2009). For example, judgements of the relative loudness of two sounds of different frequencies allow the subjective loudness to be related to the physical parameters of intensity and frequency.

These kind of experiments often suffer from uncertainty, and it is difficult to find an exact analytical representation of the sensitivity curve of the human ear. In the literature there exists different kind of weightings. The curve that will be used as a reference in this work is the A-weighting, A( f ) is defined using the auxiliary function RA( f ), as described in ANSI Standards S1.4-1983 and S1.42-2001: (33)RA(f)=122002f4(f2+20.62)(f2+122002)(f2+107.72)(f2+737.92) as (34)A(f)=Aoff+20log(RA(f)) where the offset Aoff can be used to obtain a value of 0 dB at a certain frequency.

sec.title: 4.1.3. Choosing the number of transducers
sec.p: The first step is to determine the number of transducers to be used. Throughout this work we will consider a number of patches equal to the number of modes to be controlled. This means that it is crucial to determine the most radiating modes within the frequency range of interest, that is for f < fmax.

To this end, the modal radiation coefficients η¯i introduced in section 3.2 are used, along with the consideration of the sensitivity of the human ear. In fact, since the human ear is less sensitive at low frequency, some modes can be neglected, if their contribution to the perceived sound is too low. In order to do this, the A-weighing is considered. The function A(f) defined by Equation (34) is normalized for having a value of 0 dB when at its maximum. In this way the value A(fi) gives an absolute value of how different a sound with the same intensity is perceived.

The set of indices ξC that identify the modes to be controlled can be then identified, for instance, using the following rule: (35)ξC:=∀i/(fi<fmax)(A(fi)<τ)(η¯i>b), where τ and b are pre-defined thresholds. In common applications, the value of τ can be set at around −20 dB, which neglects the modes below 100 Hz.

sec.title: 4.1.4. Optimization of the positioning, the notion of the spatial ℋ2 norm
sec.p: The main difficulty in optimizing the positioning of piezoelectric transducers is the choice of a utility function that really represents the controller authority over the acoustic radiation of the system, in an average sense.

In vibration mechanics the utility function is usually based on some norm of the transfer function defined as the ratio of the rth transducer voltage Vr(Ω) and the transverse velocity of the plate in a point jΩŵ(x, y, Ω). For our system the transfer function has the following form: (36)Gr(x,y,Ω)=jΩw∧(x,y,Ω)Vr(Ω)=∑i=1NjΩy∧i(Ω)Φi(x,y)Vr(Ω), and from Equations (5a) and (5b) is: (37)Gr(x,y,Ω)=∑i=1NjΩγir(x,y)Φi(x,y)-Ω2+Ωi2+2jΩΩiζi, where we added the modal structural damping ζi.

The transfer function Gr(x, y, Ω) gives the response of the plate in a point and at a specific frequency. In order to average this expression on the frequency domain, the ℋ2 norm of Gr(x, y, Ω) is defined as follows: (38)‖Gr(x,y,Ω)‖22=∫-∞∞Gr(x,y,Ω)Gr*(x,y,Ω)dΩ The ℋ2 norm of Gr(x, y, Ω) can be used to obtain the global response characteristic at the point (x, y). However, it does not give any information about the responses of other parts of the structure, because it considers only the reaction at a specific location on the plate. To overcome the difficulty in obtaining the response characteristics of the entire structure, the notion of the Spatial ℋ2 norm was introduced in Halim and Moheimani (2003). The Spatial ℋ2 norm of G(x, y, Ω) is defined as: (39)ááGr(x,y,Ω)ññ22=1 2π∫-∞∞∫SGr(x,y,Ω)Gr*(x,y,Ω)drdΩ. where r ∈ S are all the points of the plate. This quantity gives a global expression of the response of the plate with respect to the voltage of the transducer.

For the orthonormality properties of the eigenfunctions, and supposing that the modes are sufficiently spaced in frequency, Equation (39) can be simplified this way: (40)ááGr(x,y,Ω)ññ22=∑i=1N‖G~ir(x,y)‖22 where G~ir(x,y,Ω)=jΩγir(x,y)-Ω2+Ωi2+2jΩΩiζi.

sec.title: 4.1.5. Modal controllability and spatial controllability
sec.p: Form Equation (39) we can see that the global response of the system is, as expected from the vibrational modes being mutually orthogonal, the sum of the contribution of each mode. Hence the function κi(x, y) can be defined as follows: (41)κi(x,y)=‖G~ir(x,y)‖2. and the modal controllability (Halim and Moheimani, 2003) is defined as: (42)ℳi(x,y)=κi(x,y)maxi=1…N(κi(x,y)). This quantity represents the control authority of a patch placed in the point (x, y) over the ith mode and optimizing the modal controllability ℳi(x, y) means finding the point (x, y) ∈ S that maximizes the coupling between the patch and the ith mode. This kind of utility function, since it is concentrated on one single mode, can be useful only when considering single-degree-of-freedom electrical controllers, but it is clearly insufficient when considering control strategies in which every patch has to be coupled with multiple modes.

Hence the need for the introduction of a quantity that represents the controller authority over the entire structure in an average sense is evident. In Halim and Moheimani (2003), in response to this need, another utility function is defined, spatial controllability: (43)𝒥(x,y)=1β∑iNκi(x,y)2 where βn=max(x,y)∈S∑iNκi(x,y)2.
With the introduction of the spatial controllability we have an average estimation of the controller authority over the entire set of N modes that are used for the modal decomposition.

A classical constrained problem for finding the optimal position for a piezoelectric patch, using the concepts of modal and spatial controllability, consists of maximising the spatial controllability, while maintaining the modal controllability of each mode i over a certain threshold bi: (44)max(x,y)∈S𝒥(x,y) for ℳi(x,y)≥bi, i=1…N

sec.title: 4.1.6. A novel utility function: the acoustic controllability
sec.p: In the literature the spatial ℋ2 norm is used to introduce the concepts of spatial controllability and modal controllability. The spatial controllability gives information about the global response of the structure, considering the entire set of modes used in the modal decomposition. Since, as seen in section 3, not all structural modes radiate with the same efficiency, one can think about a novel utility function that takes into account these acoustic behaviour differences. The concept of acoustic controllability can therefore be introduced as the controller authority over the radiated sound power, in an average sense.

Then, from the concept described in section 4.1.3 it is possible to formulate another utility function for acoustic applications. Given that the number of piezoelectric patches is limited, and given the chosen control strategy uses one transducer for each mode to be controlled, only a selected number of modes are chosen among the most radiating ones. These selected modes are identified by the set of indices ξC and determined with the use of Equation (35).

The acoustic controllability 𝒜n is then defined starting from modal controllability, introducing the definition of spatial controllability and the normalized modal efficiency ηinorm=η¯i/max(η¯i) as defined in section 3: (45)𝒜(x,y)=1β~∑i∈ξCηinormκi(x,y)2 where β~=max(x,y)∈R∑i∈ξCηinormκin(x,y)2.

The optimization of the acoustic controllability 𝒜 gives the point (x, y) ∈ S that maximizes the control authority over the acoustic radiation in the selected band. As for the spatial controllability, a classic constraint optimization is defined by: (46)max(x,y)∈S𝒜(x,y) for ℳi(x,y)≥bi, i=1…N

The presence of the constraint on the modal controllability guarantees that each mode is controlled, and permits the location of the optimal positions even if the acoustic controllability does not have a number of local maxima equal to the patches that we are considering.

sec.title: 5.1. The optimization algorithm
sec.p:
The optimization algorithm consists of the following sequence of operations:
Acoustic characterization of the structure: given the material properties of the structure, the modal radiation efficiency coefficients η~i are calculated using Equation (30). The set of modes to be controlled is obtained using Equation (35) and thus the number of transducers.
Piezolectric patch placement optimization: The optimal positioning is found using Equation (46).
Optimization of the circuit: The circuit parameters are optimized for the obtained value of the coupling coefficients using Equation (14). This algorithm will be applied to an actual case study, presented in the following sections.

sec.title: 5.2. Acoustic characterization of the host structure
sec.p: The host structure chosen for the experiments is a rectangular aluminium plate, clamped on short edges and free on the others and fixed on a wooden plate. The choice of a nonclassic case study, the clamped–clamped–free–free (C–C–F–F) plate, highlights the robustness of the proposed smart structure when dealing with nonideal boundary conditions.

As discussed in section 3 in order to maximize the sound radiation control performances of the controller with respect to the number of modes that can be controlled, an accurate analysis of the radiation properties of the plate is performed.

sec.title: 5.2.1. Vibrational and numeric analysis
sec.p: Since with the C–C–F–F boundary conditions it is not possible to analytically derive a solution for the eigenvalue problem, the finite element software (Abaqus™) was used to calculate the modal shapes. The elements used in the finite elements analysis are C3D20R, 20-node quadratic bricks, with reduced integration.

This result is then compared to the measurements on the actual structure. This has been done because usually the clamping boundary condition is not perfect, and a better optimization can be obtained by using the real values of natural frequencies. To estimate the frequency response function (FRF) of interest, the plate is excited by one piezoelectric actuator with a random band-limited signal so as to excite the first 10 modes with a frequency spectrum covering a range from near 0 to 1 kHz. A power amplifier is used to drive the piezoelectric actuator with current. It is well known that piezoelectric materials exhibit nonlinear behaviour when the level of excitation is very high. To check for nonlinearity a particular FRF measurement has been repeated a number of times using different levels and types of excitation. Thus, a suitable level of excitation has been chosen to avoid nonlinearity. A laser vibrometer provides the output. The analysis is performed with a frequency resolution of about 0.625 Hz and 30 averages.

The measured natural frequencies are compared to those obtained numerically with Abaqus™. The modal shapes calculated for the plate are plotted in Figure 2 while the resonance frequencies measured and estimated numerically are listed in Table 1. Figure 2.

sec.title: 5.3. Piezolectric patch placement optimization
sec.p: This section is dedicated to the optimization of the piezoelectric transducer positioning, following the method introduced in section 4.

The piezoelectric transducers that will be used for assembling the structures are square, and their dimensions are 2 × 2 × 0.02 cm. In order to simplify the assembly, the piezoelectric transducers will be positioned only on the upper face of the plate. This approximation holds because extensional waves can be neglected in this range of frequencies.

Several piezo elements will be connected in parallel, as done in section 4, in order to obtain a coupling matrix as orthogonal as possible and for uncoupling even modes. Since the number of modes to be controlled is equal to three, there will be three groups of transducers, each one composed of four piezoelectric patches connected in parallel.

The spatial controllability 𝒮(xn, yn) and the acoustic controllability 𝒜n(xn, yn) for the plate and for the selected modes are plotted in Figures 3 and 4 respectively. From a comparison between the two plots it is evident how the acoustic controllability permits to find optimal spots for having a more efficient control over the radiated sound power. Figure 3.

Analysing Figure 4, the best spot for maximizing the acoustic controllability seems to be near the clamping. This is true when considering perfect boundary conditions. Since in our case study, and as highlighted in the previous section, the clampings are not perfect, that zone should be avoided. This is because the optimal positioning area is very small, and since the acoustic controllability decreases roughly, this positioning will probably correspond to a small coupling coefficient.

Hence, the search for the optimal values is limited to the set of points R*. (48)R*={(x,y∈S)/(0≤x≤(a-Lpx2)) ×(0.2≤y≤(b-Lpy2))}, where a and b are the dimensions of the plate (Table 3). Table 3.

sec.p:
The structure has been assembled following the optimization procedure described in the previous section. The piezoelectric patches were bonded on the surface of the plate using a two-component structural epoxy resin at ambient temperature. The resulting smart structure is presented in Figure 6. sec.title: 5.4.1. Coupling coefficients and capacitances
sec.p: The method that has been used for measuring the piezoelectric parameters is the impedance curve fit (Carabelli and Tonoli, 2000). This method has the advantage of being very easy to apply, and of providing accurate results. Since the number of modes to be controlled is limited, only the coupling coefficients relative to those modes will be measured.

For measuring the impedance of the piezoelectric transducer a random excitation current is applied over a frequency range from near 0 to 1 kHz and the resulting voltage response is measured on the same piezoelectric transducer. This type of test requires a current source which is voltage-driven.

sec.title: 5.5. Measurements
sec.p: In this section the results of the measurements performed on the smart structure are presented.

sec.title: 5.5.1. Vibrational analysis
sec.p: To check the validity of the control, a Fast Fourier Transform (FFT) analysis was performed to calculate the FRF of the plate. To this end an OROS I/O measurement system was used. The actuator is one piezoelectric transducer placed on the lower side of the plate, driven with a random multi-sine waveform with a frequency range from 50 to 800 Hz and amplitude of the single sine-wave equal to 2 V. A power voltage amplifier TREk was used to correctly drive the transducer. A laser vibrometer and a microphone were used to measure the velocity and pressure, and, therefore, to calculate the FRF. The acquisition time is 1.6 s, which implies a frequency resolution df = 0.625 Hz. The other three groups of piezoelectric transducers are used to control plate vibrations.

The measurements in Figure 7 were obtained using a PZT patch as an actuator and by measuring the velocity with the vibrometer and shows how the proposed control reduces the amplitude of the modes of interest. The multimodal control performs differently for each mode because of the different coupling coefficients of the transducers. The presence of a resonance at 440 Hz is due to the support on which the plate is attached, and is not a structural mode of the aluminium plate. The dampings listed in Table 7 show how the control circuit efficiently damps each mode. Figure 7.

sec.p:
The measurements plotted in Figure 8 were obtained using a PZT patch as an actuator and measuring the pressure following the ISO Standard 3745:1977. The results show a considerable reduction in terms of far-field sound pressure with the proposed controller, in agreement with the results obtained in Figure 7. Several considerations can be deduced from Figure 8. First of all, although the acoustic measure is quite disturbed, due to the imperfect acoustic insulation of the testing room, the uncontrolled curve shows that the more radiating modes are those selected by the previous acoustic analysis. sec.title: 6. Conclusions
sec.p: The core of the optimization process stands in the applications of the results obtained from the analysis of the radiation properties of the structure. This allow us to concentrate the control effort only on modes that, in terms of radiation efficiency, are the most important, using a small number of transducers and a simpler circuit, for efficient control of the radiated sound power over a large band. The optimization of the number of transducers to be used, that is equal to the number of modes to be controlled, has been obtained by exploiting the results presented in section 3 concerning modal radiation efficiency and the sensitivity of human hearing. Then an original procedure for the optimization of the placement of the piezoelectric patches was presented, along with the introduction of a novel utility function, the acoustic controllability.
This utility function considers the authority of the control system over the overall acoustic radiation, giving the best positioning for effectively control the most radiating modes.

A smart plate with clamped–clamped–free–free boundary conditions was designed, optimized and assembled following the proposed procedure and the control system was realized using a real-time I/O controller. The measurements show how in a real case study the proposed design and optimization procedure gives excellent results for the control of radiated sound power. The application of the procedure to this nonclassic boundary conditions permits us to highlight the robustness of the proposed controller when dealing with nonideal boundaries. The measurements show that the optimization procedure effectively selects the most radiating modes, and the use of the acoustic controllability as a utility function permits excellent patch positioning without performing complicated calculations.
